1. Prevent padding and border from affecting element width. (https://github.com/mozdevs/cssremedy/issues/4)
2. Allow adding a border to an element by just adding a border-width. (https://github.com/tailwindcss/tailwindcss/pull/116)
*/

*,
::before,
::after {
  box-sizing: border-box; /* 1 */
  border-width: 0; /* 2 */
  border-style: solid; /* 2 */
  border-color: #e5e7eb; /* 2 */
}

::before,
::after {
  --tw-content: '';
}

/*
1. Use a consistent sensible line-height in all browsers.
2. Prevent adjustments of font size after orientation changes in iOS.
3. Use a more readable tab size.
4. Use the user's configured `sans` font-family by default.
5. Use the user's configured `sans` font-feature-settings by default.
6. Use the user's configured `sans` font-variation-settings by default.
7. Disable tap highlights on iOS
*/

html,
:host {
  line-height: 1.5; /* 1 */
  -webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%; /* 2 */
  -moz-tab-size: 4; /* 3 */
  -o-tab-size: 4;
     tab-size: 4; /* 3 */
  font-family: ui-sans-serif, system-ui, sans-serif, "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol", "Noto Color Emoji"; /* 4 */
  font-feature-settings: normal; /* 5 */
  font-variation-settings: normal; /* 6 */
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; /* 7 */
}

/*
1. Remove the margin in all browsers.
2. Inherit line-height from `html` so users can set them as a class directly on the `html` element.
*/

body {
  margin: 0; /* 1 */
  line-height: inherit; /* 2 */
}

/*
1. Add the correct height in Firefox.
2. Correct the inheritance of border color in Firefox. (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190655)
3. Ensure horizontal rules are visible by default.
*/

hr {
  height: 0; /* 1 */
  color: inherit; /* 2 */
  border-top-width: 1px; /* 3 */
}

/*
Add the correct text decoration in Chrome, Edge, and Safari.
*/

abbr:where([title]) {
  -webkit-text-decoration: underline dotted;
          text-decoration: underline dotted;
}

/*
Remove the default font size and weight for headings.
*/

h1,
h2,
h3,
h4,
h5,
h6 {
  font-size: inherit;
  font-weight: inherit;
}

/*
Reset links to optimize for opt-in styling instead of opt-out.
*/

a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: inherit;
}

/*
Add the correct font weight in Edge and Safari.
*/

b,
strong {
  font-weight: bolder;
}

/*
1. Use the user's configured `mono` font-family by default.
2. Use the user's configured `mono` font-feature-settings by default.
3. Use the user's configured `mono` font-variation-settings by default.
4. Correct the odd `em` font sizing in all browsers.
*/

code,
kbd,
samp,
pre {
  font-family: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Liberation Mono", "Courier New", monospace; /* 1 */
  font-feature-settings: normal; /* 2 */
  font-variation-settings: normal; /* 3 */
  font-size: 1em; /* 4 */
}

/*
Add the correct font size in all browsers.
*/

small {
  font-size: 80%;
}

/*
Prevent `sub` and `sup` elements from affecting the line height in all browsers.
*/

sub,
sup {
  font-size: 75%;
  line-height: 0;
  position: relative;
  vertical-align: baseline;
}

sub {
  bottom: -0.25em;
}

sup {
  top: -0.5em;
}

/*
1. Remove text indentation from table contents in Chrome and Safari. (https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=999088, https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=201297)
2. Correct table border color inheritance in all Chrome and Safari. (https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=935729, https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=195016)
3. Remove gaps between table borders by default.
*/

table {
  text-indent: 0; /* 1 */
  border-color: inherit; /* 2 */
  border-collapse: collapse; /* 3 */
}

/*
1. Change the font styles in all browsers.
2. Remove the margin in Firefox and Safari.
3. Remove default padding in all browsers.
*/

button,
input,
optgroup,
select,
textarea {
  font-family: inherit; /* 1 */
  font-feature-settings: inherit; /* 1 */
  font-variation-settings: inherit; /* 1 */
  font-size: 100%; /* 1 */
  font-weight: inherit; /* 1 */
  line-height: inherit; /* 1 */
  letter-spacing: inherit; /* 1 */
  color: inherit; /* 1 */
  margin: 0; /* 2 */
  padding: 0; /* 3 */
}

/*
Remove the inheritance of text transform in Edge and Firefox.
*/

button,
select {
  text-transform: none;
}

/*
1. Correct the inability to style clickable types in iOS and Safari.
2. Remove default button styles.
*/

button,
input:where([type='button']),
input:where([type='reset']),
input:where([type='submit']) {
  -webkit-appearance: button; /* 1 */
  background-color: transparent; /* 2 */
  background-image: none; /* 2 */
}

/*
Use the modern Firefox focus style for all focusable elements.
*/

:-moz-focusring {
  outline: auto;
}

/*
Remove the additional `:invalid` styles in Firefox. (https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/2f9eacd9d3d995c937b4251a5557d95d494c9be1/layout/style/res/forms.css#L728-L737)
*/

:-moz-ui-invalid {
  box-shadow: none;
}

/*
Add the correct vertical alignment in Chrome and Firefox.
*/

progress {
  vertical-align: baseline;
}

/*
Correct the cursor style of increment and decrement buttons in Safari.
*/

::-webkit-inner-spin-button,
::-webkit-outer-spin-button {
  height: auto;
}

/*
1. Correct the odd appearance in Chrome and Safari.
2. Correct the outline style in Safari.
*/

[type='search'] {
  -webkit-appearance: textfield; /* 1 */
  outline-offset: -2px; /* 2 */
}

/*
Remove the inner padding in Chrome and Safari on macOS.
*/

::-webkit-search-decoration {
  -webkit-appearance: none;
}

/*
1. Correct the inability to style clickable types in iOS and Safari.
2. Change font properties to `inherit` in Safari.
*/

::-webkit-file-upload-button {
  -webkit-appearance: button; /* 1 */
  font: inherit; /* 2 */
}

/*
Add the correct display in Chrome and Safari.
*/

summary {
  display: list-item;
}

/*
Removes the default spacing and border for appropriate elements.
*/

blockquote,
dl,
dd,
h1,
h2,
h3,
h4,
h5,
h6,
hr,
figure,
p,
pre {
  margin: 0;
}

fieldset {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

legend {
  padding: 0;
}

ol,
ul,
menu {
  list-style: none;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

/*
Reset default styling for dialogs.
*/
dialog {
  padding: 0;
}

/*
Prevent resizing textareas horizontally by default.
*/

textarea {
  resize: vertical;
}

/*
1. Reset the default placeholder opacity in Firefox. (https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/issues/3300)
2. Set the default placeholder color to the user's configured gray 400 color.
*/

input::-moz-placeholder, textarea::-moz-placeholder {
  opacity: 1; /* 1 */
  color: #9ca3af; /* 2 */
}

input::placeholder,
textarea::placeholder {
  opacity: 1; /* 1 */
  color: #9ca3af; /* 2 */
}

/*
Set the default cursor for buttons.
*/

button,
[role="button"] {
  cursor: pointer;
}

/*
Make sure disabled buttons don't get the pointer cursor.
*/
:disabled {
  cursor: default;
}

/*
1. Make replaced elements `display: block` by default. (https://github.com/mozdevs/cssremedy/issues/14)
2. Add `vertical-align: middle` to align replaced elements more sensibly by default. (https://github.com/jensimmons/cssremedy/issues/14#issuecomment-634934210)
   This can trigger a poorly considered lint error in some tools but is included by design.
*/

img,
svg,
video,
canvas,
audio,
iframe,
embed,
object {
  display: block; /* 1 */
  vertical-align: middle; /* 2 */
}

/*
Constrain images and videos to the parent width and preserve their intrinsic aspect ratio. (https://github.com/mozdevs/cssremedy/issues/14)
*/

img,
video {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

/* Make elements with the HTML hidden attribute stay hidden by default */
[hidden] {
  display: none;
}

.post-block-show {
  font-size: 14px;
  text-align: center;
  border: 1px solid #fabf2c;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  padding: 18px 24px;
}
.post-block-show a {
  color: #08a0ff;
  border-bottom: 1px solid #08a0ff;
  text-decoration: none;
  transition: color 0.3s, border-color 0.3s;
}
.post-block-show a:hover {
  text-decoration: none;
  border-color: #0666a1;
  color: #0666a1;
}
@media (min-width: 768px) {
.post-block-show {
    font-size: 16px;
}

text-center">COINTELEGRAPH IN YOUR SOCIAL FEED</div><!----></div><div class="post__content-wrapper" data-v-0ccfa88e><!----><div class="post-content relative" data-v-0ccfa88e><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">Rich Dad Poor Dad author Robert Kiyosaki has doubled down on his bullish outlook for hard assets, saying he’s buying more gold, silver, Bitcoin and Ethereum even as markets brace for a potential crash.</p><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">In a <a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://x.com/theRealKiyosaki/status/1987387131174535335" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank">post</a> shared on X on Sunday, Kiyosaki warned of an impending economic downturn but said he’s preparing for it by accumulating assets he calls “real money.” </p><p>“Crash coming: Why I am buying, not selling,” he wrote, setting ambitious targets of $27,000 for gold, $100 for silver and $250,000 for Bitcoin (<a href="/bitcoin-price">BTC</a>) by 2026.</p><p>Kiyosaki said his gold projection came from economist Jim Rickards, while his $250,000 Bitcoin target aligns with his long-held view of BTC as protection against the Federal Reserve’s “fake money.” </p><figure><img alt='' src='https://s3.cointelegraph.com/uploads/2025-11/019a67ee-11a2-7185-b4ca-182f7bbe7dff' title='' /><figcaption style='text-align: center;'><em>Kiyosaki remains bullish on Bitcoin, Ether, gold and silver. Source: </em><a href="https://x.com/theRealKiyosaki/status/1987387131174535335" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" title="https://x.com/theRealKiyosaki/status/1987387131174535335"><em>Robert Kiyosaki</em></a></figcaption></figure><p><em><strong>Related: </strong></em><a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://cointelegraph.com/news/bitcoin-unofficial-ipo-phase-jordi-visser-analysis?utm_source=rss_feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound"><em><strong>Bitcoin is having its IPO moment, says Wall Street veteran</strong></em></a></p><h2>Kiyosaki turns bullish on Ether, citing Tom Lee’s call</h2><p>Kiyosaki is also turning bullish on Ether (<a href="/ethereum-price">ETH</a>). Inspired by Fundstrat’s Tom Lee, Kiyosaki said he views Ethereum as the blockchain powering stablecoins, giving it a unique edge in global finance. </p><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">He explained that his conviction in these assets stems from Gresham’s Law, which says that bad money drives out good, and Metcalfe’s Law, which ties network value to the number of users.</p><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">Kiyosaki, who claims to own both gold and silver mines, criticized the US Treasury and Federal Reserve for “printing fake money” to cover debts, calling the United States “the biggest debtor nation in history.” He repeated his well-known mantra that “savers are losers,” urging investors to buy real assets even during market corrections.</p><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">Meanwhile, on-chain data appears to support a potential turnaround for Bitcoin. Market analytics platform Crypto Crib <a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://x.com/Crypto_Crib_/status/1987439063989961031" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank">noted</a> that Bitcoin’s Market Value by Realised Value (MVRV) ratio, a key indicator of market value versus realized value, has returned to 1.8, a level that has historically preceded 30–50% rebounds.</p><figure><img alt='' src='https://s3.cointelegraph.com/uploads/2025-11/019a67ee-f17d-7e44-92e3-cc5f4eb02ce1' title='' /><figcaption style='text-align: center;'><em>Analyst Crypto Crib sees a rebound incoming. Source: </em><a href="https://x.com/Crypto_Crib_/status/1987439063989961031" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" title="https://x.com/Crypto_Crib_/status/1987439063989961031"><em>Crypto Crib</em></a></figcaption></figure><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined"><em><strong>Related: </strong></em><a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://cointelegraph.com/news/france-law-bitcoin-supply-reserve-asset"><em><strong>French Gov’t Set to Review Motion to ‘Embrace Bitcoin and Cryptocurrencies’</strong></em></a></p><h2>Hayes says rising US debt will fuel Bitcoin rally</h2><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">Last week, former BitMEX CEO Arthur Hayes said that the Federal Reserve <a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://cointelegraph.com/news/bitcoin-below-100k-analysts-bullish-outlook?utm_source=rss_feed&amp%3Butm_medium=rss_tag_bitcoin&amp%3Butm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound">will be forced into a form</a> of “stealth quantitative easing (QE)” as US government debt continues to surge. He said the Fed will likely inject liquidity into the financial system through its Standing Repo Facility to help finance Treasury debt without officially calling it QE.</p><template data-ct-widget="buzzsprout" data-buzzsprout-podcast-id="2040516" data-buzzsprout-episode-id="18149921"></template><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined">According to Hayes, this quiet balance sheet expansion will be “dollar liquidity positive”, ultimately driving up asset prices, particularly Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. </p><p data-ct-non-breakable="undefined"><em><strong>Magazine:</strong></em><a data-ct-non-breakable="null" href="https://cointelegraph.com/magazine/bitcoin-kyle-chasse-venture-capitalist-youtube-strike-cointelegraph/"><em><strong> Bitcoin OG Kyle Chassé is one strike away from a YouTube permaban</strong></em></a></p><template data-name='subscription_form' data-type='crypto_biz' data-ct-non-breakable='undefined' label='Subscription Form: Crypto Biz Newsletter'></template></div><!----><!----><div class="post__separator-line" data-v-0ccfa88e></div><div class="tags-list post__block post__block_tags" data-v-0ccfa88e><ul class="tags-list__list"><li reach $250,000 and gold $27,000 by 2026, saying he’s buying hard assets amid a looming crash.";cC.twitterLeadText=cA;cC.badgeSlug=cx;cC.badgeName=Z;cC.fullText="\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003ERich Dad Poor Dad author Robert Kiyosaki has doubled down on his bullish outlook for hard assets, saying he’s buying more gold, silver, Bitcoin and Ethereum even as markets brace for a potential crash.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003EIn a \u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\"null\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Epost\u003C\u002Fa\u003E shared on X on Sunday, Kiyosaki warned of an impending economic downturn but said he’s preparing for it by accumulating assets he calls “real money.” \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E“Crash coming: Why I am buying, not selling,” he wrote, setting ambitious targets of $27,000 for gold, $100 for silver and $250,000 for Bitcoin (\u003Ca href=\"\u002Fbitcoin-price\"\u003EBTC\u003C\u002Fa\u003E) by 2026.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EKiyosaki said his gold projection came from economist Jim Rickards, while his $250,000 Bitcoin target aligns with his long-held view of BTC as protection against the Federal Reserve’s “fake money.” \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg alt='' src='https:\u002F\u002Fs3.cointelegraph.com\u002Fuploads\u002F2025-11\u002F019a67ee-11a2-7185-b4ca-182f7bbe7dff' title='' \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption style='text-align: center;'\u003E\u003Cem\u003EKiyosaki remains bullish on Bitcoin, Ether, gold and silver. Source: \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ERobert Kiyosaki\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERelated: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\"null\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcointelegraph.com\u002Fnews\u002Fbitcoin-unofficial-ipo-phase-jordi-visser-analysis?utm_source=rss_feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBitcoin is having its IPO moment, says Wall Street veteran\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EKiyosaki turns bullish on Ether, citing Tom Lee’s call\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\u003Cp\u003EKiyosaki is also turning bullish on Ether (\u003Ca href=\"\u002Fethereum-price\"\u003EETH\u003C\u002Fa\u003E). Inspired by Fundstrat’s Tom Lee, Kiyosaki said he views Ethereum as the blockchain powering stablecoins, giving it a unique edge in global finance. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003EHe explained that his conviction in these assets stems from Gresham’s Law, which says that bad money drives out good, and Metcalfe’s Law, which ties network value to the number of users.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003EKiyosaki, who claims to own both gold and silver mines, criticized the US Treasury and Federal Reserve for “printing fake money” to cover debts, calling the United States “the biggest debtor nation in history.” He repeated his well-known mantra that “savers are losers,” urging investors to buy real assets even during market corrections.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003EMeanwhile, on-chain data appears to support a potential turnaround for Bitcoin. Market analytics platform Crypto Crib \u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\"null\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FCrypto_Crib_\u002Fstatus\u002F1987439063989961031\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Enoted\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that Bitcoin’s Market Value by Realised Value (MVRV) ratio, a key indicator of market value versus realized value, has returned to 1.8, a level that has historically preceded 30–50% rebounds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg alt='' src='https:\u002F\u002Fs3.cointelegraph.com\u002Fuploads\u002F2025-11\u002F019a67ee-f17d-7e44-92e3-cc5f4eb02ce1' title='' \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption style='text-align: center;'\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAnalyst Crypto Crib sees a rebound incoming. Source: \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FCrypto_Crib_\u002Fstatus\u002F1987439063989961031\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FCrypto_Crib_\u002Fstatus\u002F1987439063989961031\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ECrypto Crib\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERelated: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\"null\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcointelegraph.com\u002Fnews\u002Ffrance-law-bitcoin-supply-reserve-asset\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFrench Gov’t Set to Review Motion to ‘Embrace Bitcoin and Cryptocurrencies’\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EHayes says rising US debt will fuel Bitcoin rally\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\"undefined\"\u003ELast week, former BitMEX CEO Arthur Hayes said that the Federal Reserve \u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\"null\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcointelegraph.com\u002Fnews\u002Fbitcoin-below-100k-analysts-bullish-outlook?utm_source=rss_feed&amp%3Butm_medium=rss_tag_bitcoin&amp%3Butm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound\"\u003Ewill be forced into a form\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of “stealth quantitative easing (QE)” as US government debt continues to surge. We work every day to help educate our readers and raise awareness of the intricacies and advantages offered in today’s digital revolution.\\r\\n\\r\\nWith technology breakthroughs now occurring in fields such as AI, VR, nanotech, quantum computing, and an increasing number of businesses, entrepreneurs and consumers adopting blockchain technology in everyday life, we aim to inform, educate, and share valuable information with our readers.\\r\\n\\r\\n\",\"__typename\":\"Translate\"},{\"key\":\"about.hero.title\",\"value\":\"About Cointelegraph\",\"__typename\":\"Translate\"},{\"key\":\"about.team.description\",\"value\":\"We are privileged enough to work with the best and brightest in cryptocurrency, blockchain and Bitcoin. Kiyosaki says he’s buying, targets $250K Bitcoin and $27K gold\",\"leadText\":\"Robert Kiyosaki predicts Bitcoin will reach $250,000 and gold $27,000 by 2026, saying he’s buying hard assets amid a looming crash.\",\"twitterLeadText\":\"Robert Kiyosaki says he’s buying gold, silver, Bitcoin and Ether despite crash warnings, targeting $250,000 BTC and $27,000 gold by 2026 as he criticizes the Fed’s policies.\",\"facebookLeadText\":\"Robert Kiyosaki says he’s buying gold, silver, Bitcoin and Ether despite crash warnings, targeting $250,000 BTC and $27,000 gold by 2026 as he criticizes the Fed’s policies.\",\"bodyText\":\"\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"undefined\\\"\u003ERich Dad Poor Dad author Robert Kiyosaki has doubled down on his bullish outlook for hard assets, saying he’s buying more gold, silver, Bitcoin and Ethereum even as markets brace for a potential crash.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"undefined\\\"\u003EIn a \u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"null\\\" href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\\\" rel=\\\"noopener nofollow\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003Epost\u003C\u002Fa\u003E shared on X on Sunday, Kiyosaki warned of an impending economic downturn but said he’s preparing for it by accumulating assets he calls “real money.” \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E“Crash coming: Why I am buying, not selling,” he wrote, setting ambitious targets of $27,000 for gold, $100 for silver and $250,000 for Bitcoin (\u003Ca href=\\\"\u002Fbitcoin-price\\\"\u003EBTC\u003C\u002Fa\u003E) by 2026.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EKiyosaki said his gold projection came from economist Jim Rickards, while his $250,000 Bitcoin target aligns with his long-held view of BTC as protection against the Federal Reserve’s “fake money.” \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg alt='' src='https:\u002F\u002Fs3.cointelegraph.com\u002Fuploads\u002F2025-11\u002F019a67ee-11a2-7185-b4ca-182f7bbe7dff' title='' \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption style='text-align: center;'\u003E\u003Cem\u003EKiyosaki remains bullish on Bitcoin, Ether, gold and silver. Source: \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow noopener\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" title=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fx.com\u002FtheRealKiyosaki\u002Fstatus\u002F1987387131174535335\\\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ERobert Kiyosaki\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERelated: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"null\\\" href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fcointelegraph.com\u002Fnews\u002Fbitcoin-unofficial-ipo-phase-jordi-visser-analysis?utm_source=rss_feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound\\\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBitcoin is having its IPO moment, says Wall Street veteran\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EKiyosaki turns bullish on Ether, citing Tom Lee’s call\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\u003Cp\u003EKiyosaki is also turning bullish on Ether (\u003Ca href=\\\"\u002Fethereum-price\\\"\u003EETH\u003C\u002Fa\u003E). Inspired by Fundstrat’s Tom Lee, Kiyosaki said he views Ethereum as the blockchain powering stablecoins, giving it a unique edge in global finance. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"undefined\\\"\u003EHe explained that his conviction in these assets stems from Gresham’s Law, which says that bad money drives out good, and Metcalfe’s Law, which ties network value to the number of users.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"undefined\\\"\u003EKiyosaki, who claims to own both gold and silver mines, criticized the US Treasury and Federal Reserve for “printing fake money” to cover debts, calling the United States “the biggest debtor nation in history.” He repeated his well-known mantra that “savers are losers,” urging investors to buy real assets even during market corrections.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp data-ct-non-breakable=\\\"undefined\\\"\u003EMeanwhile, on-chain data appears to support a potential turnaround for Bitcoin.
